channel.title: "Illegal but decriminalised"?
channel.description: I've seen on the news that in a lot of countries, marijuana possession is "illegal but decriminalised". What does this mean, exactly? I always thought that "decriminalised" effectively mean "previously illegal, now legal".

item.title: "Illegal but decriminalised"?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:3, topic:538308”][quote author=t4 link=topic=657133.msg4396277#msg4396277 date=1389221678]
It means cops can take your stash and fine you, but not arrest you (for up to certain amounts). You obviously can’t produce the plant unless local laws state so (and that is usually with certain preconditions).

Note: the above accounts for private use, I think having it on you in public/car is much more serious.
[/quote]

Ah, okay. So “decriminalised” means that it’s no longer a criminal offence?[/quote]

That’s pretty much exactly it. No criminal charges involved and therefore no criminal record. (for the defined amounts you can have)

It’s a step in the right direction but doesn’t solve anything. Only fully legalizing it will solve the issues that prohibition creates.

While USA steps in the right direction to legalization, my country Canada only makes it worse. Ironically on the day Colorado legalized it, we started mandatory minimum sentences in Canada. Cant wait to get these cons out of power.

item.title: "Illegal but decriminalised"?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:7, topic:538308”][quote author=t4 link=topic=657133.msg4396284#msg4396284 date=1389222023]

It means cops can take your stash and fine you, but not arrest you (for up to certain amounts). You obviously can’t produce the plant unless local laws state so (and that is usually with certain preconditions).

Note: the above accounts for private use, I think having it on you in public/car is much more serious.

Ah, okay. So “decriminalised” means that it’s no longer a criminal offence?

Sort of? But like I said it’s only up to certain amounts and only applies in private circumstances. Regardless, if you’re under 18 (or even 21 - I think that’s the age in CO/WA) I highly suggest not partaking in marijuana.

I’m in the UK where it’s completely illegal but the police generally turn a blind eye to usage at parties, etc. The same with drinking.

If that’s a response to the age comment I made, I want to clarify that my suggestion was not based on any jurisdiction’s’s laws. It’s rather unhealthy for adolescent development - just as is drinking.
[/quote]

Oh yeah, I understand that. I just thought you were saying it about the potential legal impacts upon one’s future.[/quote]
Well as far as implications go: if you’re not an adult authorities can call your parents. You’re also, well, not an adult so there’s a philosophical debate in itself right there.
